So the apostle says, "if our gospel be hid, it is hid to them that are lost; in whom the god of this world hath blinded the minds of them which believe not, lest the light of the glorious gospel of Christ, who is the image of God, should shine into them", 2 Corinthians 4:3, 4. The gospels show how God was presented in the Lord's ministry -- especially the gospel of Luke.
Rem. The day in which we live is different from that in which the Thessalonians lived, is it not? Idols are not honoured now as they were then.
[Page 466]
J.T. John contemplates certain ones "going out". He says, "they went out from us"; what was anti-christian went out. In the apostle's days the power amongst them was so great that the evil went out, so we read of false prophets going out; they could find no latitude among the Christians, so they went out. But subsequently they found refuge within, and in time the pagan world was christianised. But the pagan world as christianised was bound to keep the principles of idolatry in some way, and it is for us to discover by the Spirit of God what form it takes now.
B.T.F. Did you say the anti-christian spirit went out and christianised the world?
J.T. I think the Christendom of today is the work of the devil. It is christianised only in the sense that the name of Christ is on it, not in any essential way.
R.S.S. I think the form idolatry takes today, to a considerable extent, is occupation with the greatness and glory of man; it will be that in the end, because man will set himself up making himself God.
J.T. It will head up in that way, only God modifies things today for our sakes. Certain events have been permitted to check it for the sake of the saints, but the elements are all there and will be seen then in their nakedness; man will be the idol then. In the apostles' days the saints were exposed to the pagan system; Satan could not effect much now by gross idolatry, but he knows what man is prepared for; he knows man, and he produces what he wants.
C.A. I suppose, that, what will head up in the man of sin, Christ as the ark of the covenant will destroy publicly.
J.T. The ark of the covenant is the exact opposite to all that. Christ came in God's name doing God's
[Page 467]
will, the man of sin will come in his own name doing his own will.
P.H.P. Would you say, that idolatry is anything that displaces God in the heart?
J.T. Yes, in principle. Idolatry is really connected with the devil; a stick or a stone is not evil in itself; the evil is in Satan using it to displace God in the heart.
C.A. Could natural relationships be idols?
J.T. Anything is that Satan can use to displace God in the heart; that is the clue; you must decide for yourself what it is in your own case. "The things which the Gentiles sacrifice they sacrifice to demons and not to God". It is connected with the devil. Idolatry must always be met by bringing God in; so your great exercise in presenting the testimony is to bring God in. We are to be formed by the knowledge of God, we are born of God and as knowing God we are able to present Him. "God who commanded the light to shine hath shined in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God". The light shines into our hearts for the shining forth.
R.S.S. Mr. Raven once said, 'I think I can say, I always seek to present God in Christ as I know God and Christ. You must speak from conscious knowledge if you are to have much power'.
J.T. That is very nice. It is most important to see what the ark represents: as soon as God has such an One as it represents the conflict begins; and God will bring all into conformity with the ark. He takes Moses up to the mount and "all flesh" is left below in the camp. What God set forth up there is really Christianity: all the wood and other material spoke of Christ, and in effect what is below is superseded; it was, in fact, idolatrous, and it took only forty days to bring this out. The instruction as to the tabernacle assumed the utter worthlessness of
[Page 468]
man in flesh. It is remarkable to think that Christians were in the mind of God on the mount as the kind of people, formed after Christ, that God would bring in.
A.F.M. The law was put in the ark, and Christ when here magnified the law and made it honourable.
J.T. That testimony is continued in us, so that the boards of the tabernacle were of the same materials as the ark; and they also were covered with gold, only they were socketed with silver; there was necessity for redemption; with the ark there was no need for that. Blue was not prominent in connection with the ark except when it was carried, but in the priestly garments blue was essential; as he entered the tabernacle the priest was to be clothed with blue. The ark is Christ in connection with God's counsels on the earth; the priest is Christ in regard to the heavenly position. Christ as typified in the ark had the law in His heart, but the priest had the saints on his heart. Christ came out to fulfil God's will, but He carried the saints in His heart into heaven.
R.S.S. There is a very beautiful picture of Christ in Isaiah 11. It is a most beautiful description of Him in another connection.
J.T. Yes, in relation to Jesse. Here it is a question of the One whom God elected. In chapter 11 it is the offspring of Jesse. Here He was elected because God delighted in Him.
R.S.S. Will you say something about verses 3 and 4?
J.T. Verse 3 I think refers to Christ as here in the exercise of His ministry. Verse 4, "he shall not fail or be discouraged till he have set judgment in the earth" refers to the ark, to its stability, durability, and strength. Strength is connected with the ark; so David says. God "delivered his strength into captivity, and his glory into the enemy's hand".
[Page 469]
B.T.F. There is a remarkable contrast between verse 3 of chapter 11 and verse 19 of this chapter.
J.T. The latter, "who is blind, but my servant", undoubtedly refers to Israel. The word servant in this book sometimes has that reference; but it is important to see what God would do in the Man that was His Servant; He would set Him as a covenant to the people; that is, through Him He would make known His mind to the people, that He might establish Himself in their hearts. If the light of God enters the heart, idolatry goes out. God will not give His glory to another, man is His image and glory, and He will not tolerate idolatry.
Ques. Will you say something about the word in John, "Little children keep yourselves from idols"?
J.T. The apostle contemplated the Christian circle as intact and it was to be kept intact.
Ques. Is that individual?
J.T. Each individual must see to it. These parental expressions refer to the apostles' place; no one else could use them.
Ques. Do verses 9 and 10 refer to Christianity?
J.T. I think so. "The former things" refer to the Old Testament; now God will bring in "new things". Christianity is new. "Before they spring forth I tell you of them". God tells us of them in advance.
B.T.F. Is that the present time?
J.T. Yes; prophecy refers to the remnant, only we are a continuation of the remnant of Israel, and what is coming in is known to us.
A.F.M. Are the new things seen in the end of the book?
J.T. Yes.
B.T.F. "I have put my Spirit upon him; he shall being forth judgment to the Gentiles". Is that fulfilled now?
[Page 470]
J.T. The principle of it is. Every right-minded person appreciates judgment. It is a happy thing to have judgment, that is, righteous discernment; it is unhappy for people to be without that. The introduction of judgment, that is, righteous discrimination, is what every right-minded person anticipates with joy.
R.S.S. There is a beautiful expression in chapter 11, verse 3, "he shall not judge after the sight of his eyes". That is the best we can do, "but with righteousness shall he judge the poor".
Ques. Was that in David's mind in Psalm 72, "Give the king thy judgments, O God"?
J.T. Just so. Solomon showed judgment in his decision between the two mothers. We should not form a judgment without testimony and evidence, but we should have a judgment as to everything, "He that is spiritual judgeth all things".
R.S.S. But he should not pronounce his judgment.
J.T. No, and in regard to evil you judge it, but you cannot punish it; you must punish yourself; that is, you suffer to be clear of it. So in the Lord's closing speeches to Israel we see everything judged, but not punished. The Lord had to suffer Himself. Moral judgment precedes the execution of it. It is seen in Christ; He judged everything; for instance we see Him going into the temple and judging.
Ques. What about judgment is His strange work?
J.T. That is executive judgment. We have our senses exercised to discern between good and evil, but if there is no means of putting down the evil we must suffer from it; we are called upon to judge a thing we cannot put down.
R.S.S. So with John the baptist; when he was executed they came and told the Lord, but they did nothing about it; the Lord saw His own rejection in it.
[Page 471]
Ques. What about, "Ye have: come to ... God the Judge of all?" Hebrews 12.
J.T. The believer has come to that now. You have come to One who is Judge of all and you leave everything with Him. You feel, "Shall not the Judge of all the earth do right?" You have your judgment, but you must leave things as they are and suffer.
R.S.S. So it is said of the Lord Himself, "When he suffered he threatened not, but committed himself to him that judgeth righteously".
J.T. Yes, that is it. There is really the most extraordinary situation existing at the present time: you judge all, and yet you have to suffer from the evil. The Lord Himself suffered under it. Faith would rather suffer from the evil than change the dispensation; the dispensation of grace is one that God delights in. "For thy sake we are killed all the day long"; the suffering goes on; the victory is that you have power to suffer.
A.F.M. I think this point is very serious; and if we take it home to ourselves it is most practical; for instance, the question of retribution in our business, our homes.
J.T. Or among the saints.
A.F.M. It is a practical question for us: How do we behave, are we retributory? Do we give evil for evil instead of overcoming evil with good?
P.H.P. We are enjoined to commit our souls unto Him in well-doing as unto a faithful Creator; even as creatures we shall be taken care of if we do right.
J.T. Oh yes, God will take care of the right, but you may have to suffer. The Lord Himself exposed everything in Israel through His ministry, but He did not remove it; He resisted unto blood striving against sin, but He went down under it. So we are called to suffer.
[Page 472]
B.T.F. So when John the baptist suffered the Lord did nothing.
J.T. Take Paul, for instance, see his sufferings; yet conditions are not changed for him. The Lord had power to bring Paul down at his conversion and He had power to alter the situation for him afterward; but He did not do the latter. So too John wrote to those "in tribulation and in the kingdom and patience of Jesus Christ". The best way to show you have a right judgment is that you have enough authority to put down the evil in yourself; it is good experience for the kingdom by and by. If you rule your spirit now you can rule cities by and by; it will be a constant exercise for you; the lawless spirit is always in us and should be kept inactive, and thus we should be a testimony to God's power.
R.S.S. There are two things, it has been said, which should characterise the Christian: to go on in self judgment, and abiding in the love of God. In that case you will have your hands full with judgment, and you will grow too. The better you know yourself the more you will consider your brother.
Rem. We have in James 5"Does anyone among you suffer evil? Let him pray". I suppose you might suffer from your brethren.
J.T. There is always an outlet for you in prayer.
[Page 473]
"MY DELIGHT IS IN HER"
Isaiah 62
J.T. In this chapter we have, I think, the collective side. Jerusalem stands for it in the Old Testament. We have been dwelling on Zion, which, as I understand it, refers to a principle; but Jerusalem presents the people formed into a city. Zion, however, is sometimes referred to as the city, but for us, it represents a divine principle. Zion refers to the sovereignty of God, as we have been saying.
R.S.S. I have no doubt that is right, but does it not also stand for protection, and has it not a special place in connection with the kingdom? I think the first mention of it in Scripture is as a "stronghold;" 2 Samuel 5:7.
J.T. I think protection is connected with the city. "In that day shall this song be sung in the land of Judah; we have a strong city; salvation will God appoint for walls and bulwarks". That is Isaiah 26. Chapter 25 is the celebration of Zion: "in this mountain" will the Lord do this and that.
R.S.S. What do you think is the connection in what I was speaking of; the stronghold of Zion?
J.T. Zion is the mountain indicating a divine principle. "Ye are come to mount Zion": it is in contrast to Sinai.
Rem. Does it set forth the throne of grace?
J.T. It is the principle of sovereign mercy: God acting for the working out of His own designs after Israel had utterly failed. The stronghold was in Zion; Zion was not the stronghold; it was in Zion. The stronghold was evidently of human construction; it was formed on it.
R.S.S. Zion is then connected with the sovereign mercy of God in contrast to Sinai. We are not come to mount Sinai, but to mount Zion.
[Page 474]
J.T. Yes, and in that scripture, Hebrews 12, you have the city presented separately, "and to the city of the living God, heavenly Jerusalem;"so you see the city is distinguished from the mount.
E.Z. Does not Zion refer to Christ as a mercy seat?
J.T. Well, I think so; only Zion Being a mountain is a centre, or seat of power. The point in Zion is that God chose it; and this meant that He was acting sovereignly for the accomplishment of His counsels, ignoring that which, having failed, had an official place on the ground of the flesh. Joseph had the firstborn's place, but he was rejected (Psalm 78), and you will find that man has always quarrelled with that. "The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers take counsel together, against the Lord and against his anointed", but then God says, "Yet have I set my king upon my holy hill of Zion", Psalm 2. God's sovereignty is seen in that. God does what He pleases when He pleases and where He pleases, and man's activity is shut out altogether. When God acts thus it is for blessing. David secured mount Zion, and then blessing for the people followed, 2 Samuel 6:19. This is seen also in Psalm 132and Psalm 133. The blessing is commanded in Zion; "there the Lord commanded the blessing, even life for evermore".
R.S.S. Is the thought of Christ risen connected with it?
J.T. I think that is what it is. Man has to come to that point, and it is disastrous for him to quarrel with it.
A.F.M. Mount Zion shows how God comes in after the breakdown of the people.
J.T. When Saul was anointed, Samuel called attention to "the hill of God", that there was a garrison of the Philistines there; 1 Samuel 10:5.
[Page 475]
In faith he took account of a certain hill as belonging to God. David laid hold of that in principle also, that God had a hill; and I have no doubt Zion answers to that, and David, as anointed, repairs to Zion and takes the city. I am not prepared to say that the hill that Samuel thought of was Zion, but it is that in principle. If Saul had been with God he would have felt that the hill of God should not be in the enemy's hands. And later on we see that it is from that centre that the administration goes out. There is nothing wiser on the part of man than to submit, for it is the point of blessing. "There the Lord commanded the blessing, even life for evermore".
It may be well for us to be reminded here that it is not exactly to find out what this book teaches that we are considering it, but to get thoughts applicable to ourselves now. There are certain lines of thought on the surface, and the chapters following chapter 42 develop the controversy between God and idolatry; the instruction in it is to set you free from idolatry. God, having Christ, proposes to delete the principles of idolatry from man's heart. In chapter 51, a people are appealed to whofollow righteousness; then there is the appeal; "Awake, awake, put on thy strength, O, Zion, put on thy beautiful garments, O, Jerusalem", chapter 52: 1. Here we have the collective side, but for this, man must be delivered from idolatry and lawlessness; chapter 51 shows that this had taken place. I do not know anything more important than to see, that God, having found the Servant in Christ, He undertook to accomplish it.
The remainder of the book, from chapter 49 onwards, gives the magnificent disclosure of God's designs in Jerusalem, leading up to new creation in the last two chapters. The counsels of God with regard to Zion are to be accomplished, and you get that in this chapter.
[Page 476]
C.A. And having been accomplished, blessing flows out.
J.T. "Awake, O, arm of the Lord", Isaiah 51:9. Faith recognises the power of God: that is a great point reached; it is brought to pass in Christ. "Awake, put on strength, O, arm of the Lord"; that is verse 9, and in verse 17 you find "Stand up, O, Jerusalem"; and in chapter 52, "Put on strength, O, Zion, put on thy beautiful garments, O, Jerusalem". Now I think you see there how the collective thought is reached: faith discerns the arm of the Lord, and calls upon it, and then faith turns to Jerusalem and says, "Awake". Not only was the arm of the Lord strong, but she, (the city) had strength now. The arm of the Lord is an objective thought, but if you are called upon to awake and rise up from the dust that is subjective. Faith, being present, you are enabled to loose from your moorings. You will notice there are three "Awakes" in chapter 51 and 52; verses 9 and 17 of chapter 51 and chapter 52: 1.
C.A. That comes in by way of a cry: it is the cry of the Spirit.
J.T. It has the same force, in principle, as the midnight cry, "Behold the Bridegroom". Faith sees that Jerusalem is in the dust and calls upon her to awake. The arm of the Lord has been revealed in Christ to faith; Isaiah 53:1. Faith here sees that, and calls upon the arm of the Lord to act, and turns to Jerusalem, saying, "Awake".
A.R.S. In Romans we get "knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep".
J.T. That is the principle. Saints are likely, to get sleepy; that is, the senses are dulled by occupation with things on the earth. But when there is an awakening it is a great thing to recognise the power that we have. It is one thing to have the Spirit and another thing to prove His power by using it.
[Page 477]
Ques. What is the strength?
J.T. It is the Spirit. What is said of Israel is, "I have borne you on eagles' wings, and brought you to myself"; then it is said in this book, "they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles". The strength of God is imparted to you. At Pentecost, the remnant of Israel put on the strength of Jehovah, as we see in Acts.
Rem. "Be strong in the Lord and; in the power of his might".
J.T. Yes, put it to the test, and thus you find how real it is. When Jerusalem recognises the power imparted to her, she will then "put on strength". Jerusalem is made to correspond to the arm of the Lord; and following this, those who announce the gospel are alluded to in the most touching manner; chapter 52: 7. "How beautiful on the mountains are the feet of him who bringeth good tidings".
A.F.M. Christ had been justified earlier; chapter 50: 8. I was thinking of the Spirit being here in connection with Christ up there; Acts 2.
J.T. Jerusalem (or the remnant) established in faith is in connection with the Messiah -- God justified Him by the gift of the Spirit. In the issue between Christ and Israel, God must be the Arbiter; He would decide where right was. The Lord said in spirit, "he is near that justifieth me". God justified Christ in raising Him from among the dead; but there was more than this, He was not seen as risen by the world, but His disciples remained, and they were seen as having received the Holy Spirit from Christ glorified. The Lord said that when He should come He would bring demonstration to the world of sin, of righteousness and of judgment. The Spirit brought the demonstration of righteousness into the world. The gift of the Spirit to the disciples, the followers of Jesus, was God's way of demonstrating
[Page 478]
that He had decided for Christ. Christ was put to death for the testimony, and it remained for God to show whether He had justified Christ or not. Israel assumed that they were doing service in putting Christ to death. The Lord said that when the Spirit should come. He would bring demonstration to the world of sin, righteousness and judgment.
Rem. The Spirit brought these things into evidence.
L.T.F. Justified in the Spirit in Timothy, is that the same?
J.T. I think it is; it is a testimony to God's estimate of Christ, whom the world slew.
A.F.M. It is the standing proof of what God has done in Christ.
J.T. Yes, and so Peter in Acts 2gives an explanation of what had taken place, and he says "God hath made that same Jesus, whom ye have crucified, both Lord and Christ"; being exalted, He had received of the Father the promise of the Spirit, and had shed forth that which they saw and heard.
W.B. Israel did not accept that at that time.
J.T. But it was a very great overture on the part of God to Israel; it was as though God said, 'I have made a decision in regard to Christ, and if you bow to that decision you will get the good of what is in Christ, what He is now administering'.
W.B. Will Israel accept that justification in the future?
J.T. They will accept it on the day of atonement; the awakening will take place at the feast of trumpets. Israel had slept, but now God calls on Israel-to put on strength: in principle it was there at Pentecost.
Ques. Was that the power of the kingdom?
J.T. The power of the Spirit was there. The "arm of the Lord" is seen in the resurrection of Christ: "Then the Lord awaked as one out of sleep, and like a mighty man that shouteth by
[Page 479]
reason of wine", Psalm 78:65. The "arm of the Lord" is seen in raising Christ from the dead; that same strength is now available for us, as it will be for Israel in the future.
R.S.S. Referring to the feast of trumpets, it occurred in the seventh month, "On the first day of the month shall ye have a sabbath, a memorial of blowing of trumpets", Leviticus 23:24; then it says, "On the tenth day of this seventh month there shall be a day of atonement".
J.T. The feast of tabernacles follows. It is necessary, not only to recognise strength, but to put it on. God is thinking of what is going to represent Him; it came out in Christ, and now it is to characterise the saints.
J.S. Is this seen at Pentecost?
J.T. It is seen at Pentecost, and when you come to chapter 60, you have an additional thought, and that is, "Arise, shine for thy light is come".
A.F.M. Awake first, rise up next.
J.T. Yes, and you arise in order to shine. "Arise, shine, for thy light is come".
B.T.F. Is that the testimony of the church now?
J.T. It is it in principle. "Arise, shine for ... the glory of the Lord is risen upon thee", refers to God's face being turned toward Israel. All this was there at Pentecost, but the nation did not answer to it. But it will do so in a future day. God was loath to give up the Jews: but He will revert to them and then the day of Israel's mourning shall be over. In chapter 60 the days of mourning are contemplated as ended. Chapter 62 indicates the great place Israel is to have in relation to Jehovah.
Rem. The Gentiles are in view.
J.T. They come in subordinately to the Jew.
A.R.S. Would the man at the beautiful gate of the temple be an example of one who puts on strength?
[Page 480]
J.T. Yes, chapter 60 is marvellous as showing the great issue of the controversy, and how God established mount Zion and Jerusalem. In Psalm 48we learn that Zion is the joy of the whole earth.
Isaiah 61comes in as showing what the ministry of Christ was; it was a ministry of grace, and this continues to the present time. The Spirit of the Lord God was upon Him. He was proclaiming the acceptable year of the Lord. It was not the day of the Lord, but the year of the Lord, the longest period in the cycle. That is the period we are in. One would not wish to bring the dispensation to a close because of its being the acceptable year.
Rem. The Spirit cries, "Even so come Lord Jesus", Revelation 22.
A.N.W. But what you have to say is, "Let him that is athirst come".
P.H.P. We often sing Take Thy poor waiting pilgrims home. Is that a selfish thought?
J.T. It is much greater to be in accord with the mind of God, and in sympathy with Him.
R.S.S. I think that is a great point. Paul could say, "to depart and to be with Christ which is far better", but what he had before him was to continue here for the sake of the saints.
C.A. What do you mean by God's face turning toward Israel?
J.T. It is not toward Israel now; it is turned toward the Gentiles. Here it is "thy light". It is Israel's light; that is the light of the accomplishment of the promises. This was true at Pentecost, and in the period that followed until the death of Stephen, and even after this as to the Jews outside Jerusalem, for all through the Acts they are considered first; but there is now a total eclipse as regards Israel. God's face is hidden from them, but is toward the Gentiles. Both Paul and John quote Isaiah 6as showing that the Jews had decided their own
[Page 481]
judgment in refusing, first, the testimony of Christ, and afterwards that of the Spirit; so that God was justified in turning away from them to the Gentiles; compare John 12and Acts 28. The glory of God now shines in the face of Jesus for the Gentiles, 2 Corinthians 4.
A.R.S. "Arise, shine"; can we apply that to John 3:16.
J.T. Yes, now is the day of salvation; it is the day in which God's face is towards the Gentiles, and it is for them to receive His salvation. The Spirit of Christ pursued the Jew to every part of the world until their rejection of Christ was final. When Paul went to Rome, he was so under the influence of that Spirit, that instead of sending for the brethren, he sends to the Jews and reasons with them. It was a remarkable testimony.
B.T.F. A believer should be looking for the coming of the Lord.
J.T. Yes, surely; affection for Christ leads us to look for His coming, which is the proper hope of the church, but at the same time sympathy with God in the dispensation of grace should be cultivated. We are in the "kingdom and patience of Jesus Christ". You know that evil is here, but you would rather suffer from the evil than miss being in the patience of Christ.
I do riot know anything so irrepressible as the spirit of evangelisation. Acts 8records a terrible attack of Satan against the church, but the spirit of evangelisation was active in Philip. In that chapter, the man who is formally called an evangelist is given great prominence. "The acceptable year of the Lord" is the period in which God has special pleasure, and so it is lengthened out: it is really the longest of any dispensation. It is longer than the millennium.
[Page 482]
A.F.M. The church says "Come", but at the same time there is the invitation to those in need around to come and take the water of life freely.
J.T. Sceptical people would discourage you and say "Where is the promise of his coming?" Unbelief is in opposition to God, 2 Peter 3; but faith considers the long suffering of God as salvation, and you are content to suffer in sympathy with Him.
A.R.S. "God is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness".
J.T. It is by the sovereignty of God that He has decreed the length of the dispensation.
B.T.F. You were speaking of the spirit of evangelisation being irrepressible; some say that the gospel is being given up.
J.T. Perhaps it is, but while the Spirit remains here the preaching will go on. Saul made havoc of the church, but in spite of that, evangelisation went on. Philip went to Samaria to the desert, and to Azotus, and all the cities, to Caesarea and preached the gospel. Philip, gauged the message to the audience; to the Samaritans he "preached Christ"; it was necessary that they should submit to that. To the eunuch he preached "Jesus". The gospel involves the anointed vessel, the Christ; and it also presents the only order of man that is now before God. If you bring in these two thoughts, you will not be popular. Faith in Christ involves separation, and so baptism is necessary to it. Philip went into the water with the eunuch; he accepts death himself.
I have no difficulty in preaching to saints. It is a great pity for small companies of saints to give up preaching, because if the preaching is in the power of the Spirit there will be something to benefit all.
Ques. You would preach differently to an audience of saints from what you would to a company of sinners?
[Page 483]
J.T. You would not have to call upon them to repent; you could not say that to Christians. I have heard men say there was no liberty because only Christians were present, but in the gospel there is much for the saints.
R.S.S. Paul was prepared to preach at Rome also. The expression gospel is often used in a very limited way. Those to whom Paul wrote were Christians.
J.T. You will find that where the collective side is recognised, you have multiplication. In Acts 9after the persecution was withdrawn, they were edified and multiplied.
A.F.M. Is that the thought in the "barren woman" keeping house, and being "a joyful mother of children"?
J.T. Yes, if a mother does not know how to keep house, what a disadvantage the children are at; but if the house is in order, God gives children.
B.T.F. What about testimony outside; we preach the word in our rooms, but what about carrying it into the street?
J.T. That is all right. I think God would bless every effort if made in a lowly spirit. It is "beautiful feet" that are wanted. If you have not "strength" and "beautiful garments", Isaiah 52:1, 7, you only discredit what you preach.
[Page 484]
NEW CREATION
Isaiah 65:17 to end; Isaiah 66:22,23
J.T. It occurred to me that God's way in bringing to pass His thoughts in regard to His earthly people is the same in principle as that which He follows in connection with the heavenly people, so that you get in scriptures relating to Israel truths analogous to those found in connection with the church. For instance, in Isaiah you have the overthrow of idolatry, and this takes place in each individual, and then you have the marriage relation suggested in type, and also new creation. In chapter 51: 17 there is an appeal to the people to hearken, then in verse 4 He owns them as His people. All this shows how we reach the collective position. The truth in its individual application is apprehended, so that righteousness is followed; chapter 52. God recognises them as His people; chapter 51: 4. The remnant are regarded as God's people as following righteousness; and then He proposes a law in regard to them. I think all this is analogous to our own position. If we are to be in relation to God we must be regulated by a law. Then in verse 7, "Hearken unto me ye that know righteousness, the people in whose heart is my law". They now know righteousness and God's law is in their heart. In this way God brings in a people who are formed after Christ. They answer to the ark of the covenant. The law was in Christ's heart; now it is in the hearts of the remnant. Then He says, "Fear ye not the reproach of man, neither be ye afraid of their revilings". As thus formed after Christ they would come into reproach and suffering, but they were not to fear.
The remnant now implores Jehovah to awake in His strength, so that they should return to Zion with gladness and joy. But Jerusalem is to awake and
[Page 485]
put on strength, chapter 52: 1. God's strength is made perfect in weakness. Then, the remnant are to know Jehovah's name; verse 6. They follow righteousness, and know righteousness, and as a consequence lawlessness is broken up in them; and then they know Jehovah, which means that idolatry is overthrown. In this way God recovers. Israel for Himself. All is really affected through the Servant, He who is introduced in chapter 42. Following upon this you get the marriage relation formed. In Psalm 45there is the spirit of admiration for Christ. "My heart is inditing a good matter". The Psalmist eulogises Christ and then the King's daughter is alluded to: "Hearken, O daughter". In eulogising Christ the Spirit appeals to the daughter; that is to say, to Jerusalem, she is called upon to incline her ear, and to forget her own people and her father's house, so that the king should desire her beauty. That is to say, Jerusalem is now prepared for Christ, and He delights in her. The Spirit sees her within. She is all glorious within; that is, in the king's apartment. I think that is in principle how we are brought into union with Christ.. So that when you come to chapter 62 of Isaiah you get the marriage relation alluded to formally. She is no longer regarded as desolate.
I have said so much thinking it would be helpful to see how the Spirit leads on to union in the development of the truth. Such lines of truth as the kingdom, the new covenant, and eternal life prepare the way for union. These three are on an ascending scale reaching up to union.
B.T.F. Referring to Psalm 45, is not what you have been speaking of the work of the Spirit in the believer producing suitability to Christ?
J.T. Her clothing is of wrought gold. She is all glorious within; the Spirit produces all that; and you find here in Isaiah that Jerusalem is called upon
[Page 486]
to awake and to put on her beautiful garments. Jerusalem will be adorned in a spiritual way, and will be in relation with Christ as the earthly bride. The Lord would not unite to Himself what is not in accord with Him. The remnant will know righteousness and follow righteousness, and they put on strength and beautiful garments. Thus they are in suitability for union so far as will be known on earth.
I think the principles are the same as to us. The church primarily came into evidence as knowing and following righteousness, and she was clothed with the grace of the Spirit. The Spirit forms us in the grace of Christ. According to Ephesians 1God has "graced" us in the Beloved. I have no doubt it is what the Spirit creates in us.
R.S.S. And it qualifies us for the great relationship in which we are set.
A.F.M. What has been before us in regard to these scriptures is interesting because it shows that divine truths are unchanging; that what applies to the earthly side also applies to the heavenly.
C.H.B. In connection with the church it says, His wife has made herself ready, she has put on the garments.
W.Br. In a sense the responsibility is with her.
J.T. Well, we see how she is brought in and presented to Christ in suitability. As to Jerusalem she was the queen in gold of Ophir; and then she is referred to as a daughter. She is the queen, companion of the King, but she is also referred to as daughter, and then there are other daughters. Jerusalem will be the great central feature for Christ on earth. This is the theme of the Song of Solomon.
I think the idea of a city being the companion of Christ is easily understood, and the same thing applies to the church. It suggests I think, that the relation of the bride to Christ is in connection with
[Page 487]
the government of the world. The church is formed after Christ so that she reflects Him in the character of a city.
R.S.S. It has been a question in one's mind as to what the relationship involved. I mean that the two figures, the bride and the city, did not seem to go very well together.
J.T. I think the bride comes in in connection with government. Jerusalem is called "the queen". The very term is royal, and royalty is necessarily connected with government; so that I suppose the remnant of Israel will be formed after Christ according to what He was amongst them in holy discrimination. A sceptre of uprightness shall be the sceptre of His kingdom, and this came out in His ministry on earth, and the remnant will be formed accordingly, Jerusalem will thus be "the queen in gold of Ophir".
A.F.M. What they failed to do under law in the past dispensation they will do thoroughly in the time to come. Through them there will be an administration of righteous government on earth, and love will be the motive principle.
J.T. Isaiah 53shows how the remnant will feel and own their want of appreciation of the Messiah when He was in humiliation amongst them. They saw no beauty in Him then, but it was there, and now they recognise it. The spirit of prophecy goes on to say what He was, so that you have an outline of what Christ was in humiliation and rejection. He grew up before Jehovah as a tender plant, as a root out of a dry ground. The chapter is extremely touching, for in it the Lord's humiliation, sufferings, and death are outlined in the most perfect way by the keen sensibilities of the prophetic spirit working in the repentant remnant, which rejected Him; they now feel their sorrow in that.
W.Br. Would you say that they are prepared for marriage relationship in chapter 62?
[Page 488]
J.T. Yes, God is opening up His heart now; He says, "thou shalt be called by a new name which the mouth of the Lord shall name ... . Thou shalt no more be termed Forsaken, neither shall thy land any more be termed Desolate, but thou shalt be called Hephzibah, and thy land Beulah, for the Lord delighteth in thee, and thy land shall he married", verses 2 - 4.
B.T.F. You spoke of government in the city, regarding the queen and royalty; has that any present application, or is it looking forward to the millennium?
J.T. The government of God is carried on now in principle in the church. I think every testimony of God finds an answer in some way in the church.
R.S.S. Matthew is occupied with that side of things. The church as presented there largely takes the place of Israel in the ways of God on earth.
J.T. And qualification for this was learned from Christ. In Isaiah He is introduced as Jehovah's Servant; Israel had that place, but failed in it. Christ took the position and answered to it perfectly. Thus Jehovah's Servant is to carry out His service for Him. In chapter 65: 13 - 15 they are referred to as servants.
R.S.S. Of necessity Christ could not remain here, but the church remains here to maintain and carry out all that He witnesses to. Government is a great thought with God, and what you have been saying in connection with Israel and the church in this connection is exceedingly important.
J.T. We learn how to govern first of all by governing ourselves. We are taught how to govern in view of the millennial state of things.
J.S. So that you see the failure in Noah, which unfitted him for governing.
J.T. Noah broke down; because he did not know how to govern himself.
[Page 489]
R.S.S. "Whoso sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed", is that the indication that government was committed to Noah?
J.T. Yes. If a Christian is unable to govern himself he has no place in the assembly. He is disqualified. Matthew 18especially deals with administration. You are converted and become as a little child; this shows that you can govern yourself. It is a very great victory for a man of strong will and energy to become as a little child. You become a little child by self judgment.
W.L.P. Is that the effect of the Spirit's work in us?
R.S.S. It is illustrated perhaps in Naaman, the Syrian, who came out of Jordan with his flesh as a little child.
J.T. And as a little child you learn how God does things. So Jerusalem is to learn from Christ how to govern.
B.T.F. Would you say the government of God on the earth connected with millennial times is a reflection of the government set forth in the-heavenly city?
J.T. The divine thought, is that government is to come out of heaven. That was indicated in the beginning. The fact that the sun and moon, and stars were set in the heavens indicated that God's purpose was that government should come out of heaven.
R.S.S. In connection with our brother's question as to the church in administration in Matthew, is it not rather significant that connected with the first mention of the church is the thought of administration? The Lord committed the keys of the kingdom to Peter in Matthew 16.
J.T. You are introduced into the kingdom as a little child and nurtured up in it in the knowledge of God; you learn how He does things. Matthew 18contemplates that the Lord was to leave this
[Page 490]
scene; He was not to be here with them, but they were to carry on the administration in His absence; and He encourages them by saying that if two of them should agree concerning anything they should ask it should be done of the Father in heaven; and that if two or three should gather together in His name He would be in the midst. Thus they should receive help in carrying on divine administration.
R.S.S. And then Peter asks the question as to forgiveness.
J.T. Their administration was to be carried on in grace.
R.S.S. So that in Christianity grace is righteousness.
J.T. Government as seen in the assembly is not carried on in the way of retribution. You are in accord with the dispensation of grace, and you do not want to discontinue it, so if a brother offends seventy times seven and he confesses his guilt, you are to forgive him.
W.L.P. You say that grace is righteousness. Could grace be shown by a person who is not following righteousness?
R.S.S. I hardly think so. To demand your due may be righteous in the eye of the law, but in the light of Christianity righteousness is seen more in not demanding it.
W.Br. Do you connect righteousness with administration?
J.T. Surely, but administration is carried on in grace. You could not have the kingdom without righteousness. It does not say that righteousness is on the throne, but in a sense, righteousness is on the throne if grace is there, because it is right that grace should reign now. God has a right to be gracious. We really have no rights. God only has rights. If man has rights then God's sovereignty cannot be admitted; but God has shown (Romans 3) that man
[Page 491]
has no rights, so that the ground is clear for God to assert His righteousness, and He asserts it in grace. It is right for God to be merciful.
The dispensation is summed up in this, that grace is on the throne. The idea of a throne in Scripture is, that it is absolute, and this fact only emphasises the greatness of the moment. The reign of grace now is absolute and universal. Grace reigns through righteousness. The idea of righteousness is what is right. One is liable to think that grace is something different from righteousness, whereas it is not, but righteousness will take the form of retributive judgment presently; that is another matter.
R.S.S. In connection with what our brother was saying regarding paying one's debts, it is not a question there of grace at all. A man who buys a thing from you does not expect it to be given. It is on another basis and in connection with another order of things altogether.
J.T. The world is a sphere in which God carries on His government outside the veil, His providential government, that is one thing by itself; it is indirect. We are under the providential ways of God. But God is carrying on a direct government here as a testimony. This testimony is in the assembly. We take no hand in the government of the world, but we are to be engaged in the direct government of God in the assembly. The government of England is under the government of God, who is carrying on providential government, but it is not direct government. Direct government is carried on by the Spirit and we are under this. In God's kingdom I am under the direct government of God, whereas in the providential sphere, I am only under His indirect government. You could not think of God as directly governing any existing nation. He simply overrules things. He does not put any king or president in as David was put in. We may say that
[Page 492]
the transaction of business comes under the providential government, only the Christian cannot be untrue to the principles of God's kingdom; and these are set forth in Matthew 18.
P.H.P. Am I right in supposing that every man is under the providential government of God, whether Christian or not?
J.T. Certainly.
A.R. Would not the principles of the kingdom be shown to a certain extent in our dealings with the world?
R.S.S. There are no better principles than the divine ones, to help you in the things of this life even as stated in Matthew 18. If you have a difference with a man in business there is no better way than to see him personally.
W.B. Will the providential government of God terminate before the millennium?
J.T. In the millennial world there will be the direct government of God, whereas in the present world it is His providential government; that is to say God is holding the world in check. Satan would bring things to a head quickly if it were not for that.
Ques. Is all Christendom under the present government of God?
J.T. I do not think God takes account of Christendom as anything but Babylon. The government of God is spiritual. Baptism is that you have taken up the responsibility to answer to that, so that baptism places you outwardly in direct responsibility to Christ as Lord, and if you do not answer to that you are in rebellion.
R.S.S. I suppose we are all more or less in the good of it, although we may not be able to understand it.
J.T. New creation is spoken of in chapter 65 and 66. I have been thinking lately that there is
[Page 493]
nothing that we are less accustomed to than the idea of what is new. New creation in Israel may take a different form, but at the same time the principle is there.
Ques. Does Ezekiel bring that out where the "valley of dry bones" is alluded to?
J.T. Ezekiel has more to do with the power of God than with new creation. I think the great point in Ezekiel is resurrection. The name "Ezekiel" has reference to God's strength. Isaiah brings in new creation; it is an additional thought to resurrection. New creation has application to Israel and to the church, and indeed it has application to everything in result. "I make all things new", but the practical point I should like to emphasise is that we should be prepared for appreciation of what is new. I think that the want of this has led to adapting Christianity to the old; the endeavour is to make it fit into the old system. But God's thought was that all was to be new. From the very outset the necessity for the new is conveyed in the gospel; compare John 3. The Lord said to Nicodemus "Ye must be born again". In the epistle to the Romans we find that as Christ is raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, even-so we also should walk in newness of life. There you have the thought of our walk here in the world.
L.T.F. Creation involves quite a different thing from recovering something, it is entirely a new start.
J.T. There is also to be "new wine", and it was to be put into "new bottles", Luke 5:38.
R.S.S. Mr. Stoney composed the following lines:
"If you be true to what is new,
You'll grow in beauteous grace,
If you decline and drink old wine,
The fool is in your face".
[Page 494]
J.T. Apart from the new you cannot have Christianity.
P.H.P. In what sense do you speak of the "new"?
J.T. Look at Isaiah 42:9: "new things do I declare". I think there God indicates that whilst He would bring to pass all He had spoken of as "former things", He would declare new things.
J.S. I think the Lord showed in the gospels that He was bringing in "new wine". He says new wine is not put into old bottles. He showed from that, that He was bringing in something entirely new. Here the prophet says, "new things do I declare".
A.F.M. The householder in Matthew 13, brings out of his treasure, "things new and old".
J.T. It is remarkable that the new things come out first. The new things were really before the old. The old things I suppose are the things of Israel. The new things are what Wisdom had devised (Proverbs 8) and they were first in God's mind.
H.B. The new things should be a source of joy and gladness to us as this, Isaiah 65, indicates.
J.T. New things are things which God has kept secret.
W.L.P. The new things were in God's mind from the outset.
L.T.F. Like as in the first creation, "things which are seen were not made of things which do appear", Hebrews 11:3.
J.T. The new is not made out of the old. The old appeared. I think, however, that although new creation is referred to in this chapter 65, the application is to Israel; see verse 18. I think new creation as applied to Israel here is not strictly literal. It is rather that Jerusalem is made that which she was not before; she is created a rejoicing, the people a joy. What I mean is that it is Jerusalem
[Page 495]
on earth as it will be constituted in the millennium that is in question. The new Jerusalem is above. She is literally new, wholly a new creation, and finally this will extend to the whole universe. What is immediately in the prophet's mind here is Jerusalem on earth. Isaiah is not dealing with the universe, he is dealing with Jerusalem. In the New Testament Isaiah 65:17 is fully opened up, but in the millennium the great end reached is that Jerusalem is a rejoicing, and her people a joy. Faith in an Israelite would lay hold of the promises, of the purpose of God; faith in a Christian would embrace all the counsels of God as to the Christ. In these chapters the former is in view.
R.S.S. So shall your seed remain and your name remain; that is, will go on to the kingdom. God's thoughts for Israel are eternal.
W.B. What distinction do you make between reconciliation and new creation?
J.T. As to us new creation is essential to reconciliation, but reconciliation in Scripture is stated as an objective truth. We are reconciled through the death of Christ; as having faith in Christ, God regards you as recovered. 2 Corinthians 5speaks first of new creation and then of reconciliation.
W.Br. So that reconciliation has been effected from God's side in His Son, and new creation insures the answer to it in us.
J.T. You cannot be for God's pleasure practically apart from new creation. Reconciliation is by the death of Christ; new creation is by the Spirit.
[Page 496]
BLESSING AND CURSE
Genesis 9:18 - 27; Genesis 22:15 - 18; Genesis 27:26 - 28; Galatians 3:8 - 16.
I desire to say a word about blessing. What becomes evident in the Old Testament is, that whilst God had it ever in His mind to bless, His way of blessing was, that it should flow out through a vessel. In Noah we have the first indication of that. Noah is a remarkable figure of Christ, especially in this way, that he appeared in the midst of a world that was alienated from God, and as in that world, he became the resting place for the mind of God. As we all know, his name signifies rest. God found in him a resting place for His mind amid a world that was estranged from Him by wicked works, and finding in that way one in whom He could rest. He undertakes to set aside the world that was alienated from Him. In Noah God had the head of a new world before Him, so He was free to remove the world that caused Him grief. Noah secured everything for God and carried it through the judgment. I want you to consider that for a moment.
What a man Noah was! He evidently lacked sympathisers. Little can be said of his house in this respect; his wife and sons were saved on account of their relation to him. Noah bore testimony for God during one hundred and twenty years, and thus reared up a monument to his faith, which must have been the Occasion of much moral suffering. The building of the ark placed him in the light of a person acting without any obvious good reason; in other words, acting as if he were deprived of ordinary intelligence. That was the position that Noah occupied before the flood. And more than that, he was a man imbued with the Spirit of Christ.
[Page 497]
You will remember how Peter refers to him in 1 Peter 3:20; he speaks of Christ preaching to the spirits in prison, it was the Spirit of Christ preaching through Noah. If it was the Spirit of Christ, there must have been in Noah some expression of Christ, for, as we all know, the spirit of a man is that which gives character to him. It was in the Spirit of Christ that Noah carried on his ministry. That marked his position before the flood.
When we come to the end of Genesis 8we find a man issuing triumphantly from death; he has not only escaped, like Lot, in a later day, but he has carried everything for God through the judgment with him, he has secured everything for God. That is Noah. In this way he was a remarkable type of Christ. When the New Testament speaks of any of the men of faith it enables us to understand more fully what marked them. One is thankful to refer to Noah as having many great personal traits, but what is more, he expressed the Spirit of Christ in a lawless world; he preached by the Spirit of Christ; he laid hold of what God valued, and he appreciated it and he carried that over intact to a new world. I refer to that to show you his position in chapter 9.
On leaving the ark he thinks first of God, for God was first with him, and he takes of the clean animals and fowls and offers a burnt offering; he thought of what was due to God. I will say one word about that before I pass on to chapter 9. He was true to his name, which signified rest as I said. It was, we may say, a prophetic name given to him. It is a very great thing to be true to your name; God has put His name upon us, and the point with every believer is to be true to that. If you are true to it you are true to God. God works in us to bring us into correspondence with the worthy name by which we are called. In the burnt offerings the Lord smelled a sweet savour, and then He declared that
[Page 498]
there should be no more curse. God said, as it were, 'I am going to establish everything permanently; I am going to establish a permanent order of things now, seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat, and summer and winter, and day and night shall not cease'. No change! When you apply that to Christ, what a consideration it is! God is resting in the savour of the burnt offering! What about man? The imaginations of his heart are only evil, but the believer need not be engaged with that now, he can be engaged with Christ, the burnt offering, and it is in connection with this that there is to be no change. While the earth remaineth there is to be no change. The hymn writer says,. Change and decay in all around I see; that is true, but that is not the point; there is no change in the order of things connected with Christ. This is indicated at the end of Genesis 8.
What I want to say now is, that in the light of all we have been dwelling on, this Man must be Head. You will understand what I mean. God has appointed a Head, and Christ is the Head; the Man who has gathered up everything from the wreck and brought it into a new sphere is Head. God has made a covenant with that Man. Here Noah comes before us as a type of Christ. God enters into a covenant with Noah and with Noah's sons; this is the first time that the sons have come in for direct recognition; it sets forth our position. God has entered into a covenant with us in connection with Christ. We are thus owned of God in connection with Christ, and established in a permanent order of things.
Now I want to come to what is on my mind; this man Noah is conscious of blessing. He is the first man who may be regarded as a vessel of blessing. It is only dimly indicated that he was this, but the fact is there. I want to dwell upon that, and then
[Page 499]
I want to touch on Abraham and Isaac, but I wish first to call attention to the family of Canaan in Genesis 9. You will have noticed, that twice over we are told that Ham was the father of Canaan; he was also the father of other families; it does not say that Ham was cursed. Ham was the father of Canaan, and Canaan was cursed. I wish to say a word about that family and to seek to show how that family is identified, but before dwelling upon it I wish to make clear that we are not living in the age of the curse. The age of the curse is coming. In the ways of God the family of Canaan has come to light. It has appeared in the world, and it is very important to trace it, and to discover what are the marks of that family. I do not say there are not Canaanites at the present time, but the present moment takes character from Isaac which is blessing.
We are now living under the conditions of Genesis 27. Genesis 9contemplates a state of things where there were certain families indicated for blessing, and certain families indicated for curse. Ham dishonours his father. Here we have to distinguish between the person as he is, and that of which he is typical. What we see in Ham was the lack of personal respect due to his father; there was disregard of parental authority; whatever Noah's actual condition was he was in the position of supreme authority in the world. It is a great thing to recognise divine authority, it is the disregard of it that determines the Canaanite. The Canaanitish family has to be distinctly located. I understand that God brought in the law so that the Canaanitish family might be discovered; in the law God introduced authority; this was authority in Noah, but in the law there was the full assertion of God's rights over man.
In calling out Abraham, God says, "thou shalt be a blessing; and I will bless them that bless thee,
[Page 500]
and curse him that curseth thee". The presence of Christ here upon the earth was a peculiar testimony; it was more than the law, indeed it included the law, for the Lord had the law in His heart; but He was more than that, He was the expression of God's glory. The presence of the Lord here upon the earth brought everything to light, the conditions that existed here were fully exposed. He was the expression of divine glory here and that was the idea in the call of Abraham. It was "the God of glory" who called Abraham out, the divine glory was centred in that Man; it was fully expressed in Christ, not only centred in Him; the radiancy of the divine glory shone out in Christ. But the mass of the Jews hated him. They saw no beauty in Him. How many were there to appreciate what was in Him? Isaiah said truly, "when we shall see him, there is no beauty that we should desire him". They said, "Away with him!" Thus was the true Canaanite discovered by the presence of Jesus here in this world. His enemies cursed, Him and so exposed themselves to the curse of God. But what came to pass? Instead of the curse falling on them it fell on Christ. Were they hanged on trees? No, Christ goes to the tree Himself. Noah did not do that; he announced the curse, but he did not endure it himself.
You will remember the eighth of John's gospel. What a wonderful scene! The Lord says to the sinful woman, "has no one condemned thee?" The representatives of the law and the law-breaker were there; the woman was a true Canaanite in the sense that she had broken the law, but all went out, there was no one to condemn her. Instead of executing the curse upon her and upon her accusers, for the only difference between her and them was this, that they went out and she remained. He would bear it Himself. Both the woman and her accusers
[Page 501]
were exposed; the presence of Christ here brought everything to light in its true character; He exposed the Canaanitish family, but there was a remnant of that family, in that woman, for Christ; the Canaanitish family is retained, but it is retained for blessing.
In Galatians 3it is stated that the Lord bore the curse, and so the blessing of Abraham now comes to the nations. You will remember that it was said to Abraham that in him and his seed should all the nations of the earth be blessed; all the families should be blessed so that included the family of Canaan. The apostle said that Christ "was made a curse for us", "that we might receive the promise of the Spirit". Paul had been of the Canaanitish family. Was Saul of Tarsus a Canaanite? There never was a truer one than he. The Lord Jesus took that man's curse. Paul accepted the fact that he was in the Canaanite's position, and he says that the Lord was made a curse for him. Paul gloried in Christ having been made a curse for him; he sees that he himself was in the Canaanitish position, and that Christ having borne the curse, instead of meting it out to him, gives him the Holy Spirit, "That we", he says, "might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith". But more, "that the blessing of Abraham might come to the nations". The apostle Paul here touches Genesis 22; that is, he sees that the blessing is now in Christ; this is not the age of the curse, that age is coming on; he speaks of Christ bearing the curse, and then does not refer to that any more.
I want you to see how that, Christ having died, as typified in Isaac, in Genesis 22, God has confirmed the blessing in Him. The apostle says, "not to seeds, as of many, but as of one; and to thy seed, which is Christ". He does not say "seeds", but "seed"; that is, one, and that One is Christ. One can understand the apostle Paul referring to Genesis 22.
[Page 502]
See Galatians 3:16 - 18. The Canaanitish family is not excluded from blessing; "all families of the earth" must be included. The Canaanite was really Israel; it is a very solemn thing to have to say that; the Canaanite in the mind of God was Israel morally, for it was in that nation that disobedience had its greatest expression. Divine authority was in every way disregarded there.
Saul was the representative Canaanite. He was the embodiment of Canaanitish sentiments and spirit, and that man received "the promise of the Spirit". But it could only be through the death of the Lord Jesus. He alone was clear of the curse Himself, and so He could become a curse for us, as the apostle states. And now the Canaanitish family comes into blessing with the other families and receives the promise of the Spirit. The blessing of Abraham has arrived at the nations! They have not had to go for it, it has been brought to them. We do not want the dispensation of grace to pass away. I think faith would rather suffer evil than have the dispensation of grace out short. God delights in the present dispensation. Christ having borne the curse has gone up to heaven and thence He is dispensing the blessing of God to every family.
In regard to the age of the curse that is coming on, I want to say a very brief word. The Canaanitish family will reappear in those who do not love Jesus. That is very searching. Jesus has been in the attitude of a Blesser towards the world for nearly two thousand years. He has only kind words, words of grace, for every man. Anyone who does not love that Man comes under the curse. The apostle says: "If any man love not our Lord Jesus Christ, let him be accursed". That is terrible! Do you love Him? What about the world today? Christ has been presented as the Vessel of grace to the world, and hence the seriousness of men not appreciating
[Page 503]
Him. The apostle was so much under the power of the love of Christ, that he says in effect, 'If anyone does not love that Man, let him be anathema maranatha'. The apostle did not want the dispensation to pass away, but he knew that it would pass away, and when it does, those who do not love the Lord Jesus Christ will be accursed.
It was said that those who blessed Abraham should be blessed. The Lord's supper is the great occasion of the blessing. "The cup of blessing which we bless" really involves our appreciation of Christ. Publicly we are committed to Christ, and we express our appreciation of Christ there. Love delights in it, but where there is no love for that Man the apostle's word is, "let him be anathema maranatha". But the curse is not executed now, it will be when the Lord comes. The Lord is coming! Love delights to anticipate it, but where there is no love for Christ, it is awful; and I appeal to you that you may not be found in the family of Canaan in that day. There is hope for you now, for all families come into blessing; but when God begins to discriminate, those who do not love the Lord Jesus Christ come in for the curse.
[Page 504]
THE SOVEREIGNTY OF GOD
Isaiah 25.
What I desire to dwell upon is the sovereignty of God, and I have chosen this Scripture because it intimates that God proposes to do everything on the ground of His sovereign rights. In this way it pleased Him to accomplish certain things on a. certain mountain alluded to here. He chooses the place and the time. I think it will be found that in our hearts we quarrel with that. If you search your own heart you will probably find there a very quarrelsome disposition in regard to the sovereign rights of God. Even if you decide to come to terms with Him, you are disposed to do so according to your own thoughts. I wish to show you that for blessing you must come to God's terms. God determines the place of blessing, and He determines the manner of the blessing, and He determines the character and the extent of the blessing. All must be left unqualifiedly in the hands of God. I hope to be able to show further that it is our wisdom to do that because we shall discover in result that God can do very much better for us than we can do for ourselves, or than we could propose doing had we a thought in the matter.
Now notice the setting in which this passage is found. You will observe that the chapter is a song. You know the saints of God of old learned how to sing. What I understand by that is, that they learned how to celebrate God's ways, for a song is a celebration; they learned how to celebrate a divine intervention, and to celebrate it in a song. As Christians we too should be singers in this sense. The saints of God of old were singers; they appreciated divine interventions, and their appreciation of them was of such a character that they would
[Page 505]
celebrate them in a song. Now that is what should mark believers in Christ, for they are believers in the intervention of God for man, a wonderful intervention which involves the deliverance of man from all that is against him, and his introduction into blessings. If you are a believer in the gospel you can partake of the celebration, and you should celebrate it.
One could cite several instances in the Old Testament of the characteristic celebration of a divine act of intervention, such as the fifteenth chapter of the book of Exodus; there the people of God were in the enjoyment of deliverance from the hostile power and they celebrated it. In one respect it was the highest and proudest moment of their history, when in the full light and in the full enjoyment of God's wonderful intervention for them, as in the presence of God on the banks of the Bed Sea, they were with God. He had borne them on eagles' wings, wings of power, and brought them to Himself. There they were, the Egyptians destroyed in the waters of judgment, and they themselves were with God. A wonderful thing to be with God!
Now the gospel, rightly apprehended in your soul, sets you in relationship with God, and the effect of it is that you celebrate it, you celebrate God. "The Lord is a man of war;" "the Lord hath triumphed gloriously: the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea". That is the song of the young believer; old believers or fathers are taken up with "him that is from the beginning", 1 John 2, but the young believer celebrates God's intervention for him in Christ. The gospel sets forth God's intervention for you in Christ, and in the light of it you celebrate God, "the Lord hath triumphed gloriously". If you apprehend that God has done something for you, you celebrate it; that is God's portion. God's portion is the responsive result produced in the heart
[Page 506]
of man by the light of His intervention on man's behalf. God looks for a response in your heart to whatever He has done for you; however little you see of it, do not fail to celebrate it; that is the fruit of your lips, the sacrifice of praise giving thanks to His name.
In this chapter the prophet is engaged in that way. If you recall the teaching of the prophet in this book, you will remember that in chapter 12 there was a celebration, and then following upon that God undertakes to deal with the Gentile world. We are now in the midst of a world that is alienated from God; it is ruled by influences upon earth and influences in heaven; it is a very great system of things built up by long experience, the outcome of long and tried experience; it is a system of long and patient growth. We must not under estimate what it is; the world is a system built up by a master hand behind it. That master hand is the wicked one, and he has wonderful intelligence; in that sense he is the master hand behind the world system, and he has controlled its construction, he has designed and watched over it. You need not suppose for a moment that the world has been built up haphazard; the world is a growth, and it has been built up by the wicked one in order to annul and overthrow everything that is of God, and that is what is all round about us.
In Isaiah 24we learn that God undertakes to deal with that, and the prophet is quick to discern what God effects. It is said, "The Lord maketh the earth empty, and maketh it waste, and turneth it upside down, and scattereth abroad the inhabitants thereof". That is what God does. The earth is full of people at the present time, there is probably the largest population it ever possessed, but the Lord "maketh the earth empty". I cannot undertake to tell you how it will be accomplished, but the
[Page 507]
word is, "he maketh the earth empty ... turneth it upside down ... scattereth abroad the inhabitants thereof"; and then in verse 3 it is said, "The land shall be utterly emptied, and utterly spoiled: for the Lord hath spoken this word".
I always feel encouraged to turn attention to the world in preaching the gospel, because it is essential that you should see the character of the world in order to appreciate the necessity for the gospel. The prophet here sees God intervening; there is the world, and in his day the world was very powerful; the Assyrian was there, and the prophet sees God intervening; that is, God intervenes on the earth, He deals with things, and we believers, who have got light from God, ought not to be ignorant of the conditions that exist around us. Men are having their way apparently, but what do you see, and what do I see? I see that God is going to intervene in all this, and that is what the prophet sees here. Read on in the end of chapter 24. There God touches what is on high; in verse 19 we read, "The earth is utterly broken down, the earth is clean dissolved, the earth is moved exceedingly. The earth shall reel to and fro like a drunkard, and shall be removed like a cottage; and the transgression thereof shall be heavy upon it; and it shall fall, and not rise again". Now that is the outlook. Does it discourage you that such things are going to take place? Are your ambitions in connection with the earth? Are your hopes built up, are your cherished hopes in connection with this earth? If they are, that is a dark prospect for you; this is the end of the earth as it stands; but then. God is going to touch the higher influences: in verse 21 we read, "And it shall come to pass in that day, that the Lord shall punish the host of the high ones that are on high, and the kings of the earth upon the earth". There is the seat of the trouble; the
[Page 508]
seat of the trouble on the earth is on high; the corrupting influences are on high, and God is going to deal with them.
It is essential that young people should see this. If you set your hopes in connection with this present world, there would be no greater folly, for God is going to break it up root and branch: He touches the high ones, He punishes the host of the high ones that are on high, and the kings of the earth upon the earth, and "they shall be gathered together as prisoners in the pit, and shall be shut up in the prison, and after many days shall they be visited". In that day "the moon shall be confounded, and the sun ashamed, when the Lord of hosts shall reign in mount Zion, and in Jerusalem". I want you to think of the great end that God has in view in intervening in this world: "In that day", says the prophet, "the moon shall be confounded, and the sun ashamed"; think of those great luminaries in the heavens that have been the guide for things in the heavens, regulating things in the earth. What causes the confounding of the moon and the shaming of the sun? "The Lord of hosts shall reign in mount Zion, and in Jerusalem, and before his ancients gloriously".
What a day, what strength to faith to look on for a moment to when the Lord Jesus Christ shall sit in His glory on mount Zion; He reigns there, and the greatest natural light hides its face in shame in the light of that glory. Well might the sun hide its face when Christ died; He was the great illuminator come out from heaven; the great moral light come into the world. He was the light of the world, but He died, He disappeared from view, and the sun, as it were in sympathy with Christ, the sun veiled its face; that great moral light had come into a world of darkness, disappeared in darkness, and the sun refused to shine. It was due to Christ that
[Page 509]
the great light in the heavens should refuse to shine as God hid His face from Christ. In the day when the Lord Jesus will come out, beaming with divine glory, and He sits down there in mount Zion before His ancients gloriously, the moon shall be confounded and the sun shall be ashamed; that which showed its light on the earth during the night shall be ashamed, and the moon shall be confounded, as if there was no place for it in the presence of that light, and the sun itself shall be ashamed. That is the end of the great intervention of God, and we can well understand the prophet's celebration of it. Was it not worth being celebrated? He praises God, the God who has done all this. How much fruit does God get from you? God seeks fruit, and the fruit that He seeks is the outcome, the effect of the light of Himself.
One loves to think of Moses and David. David was called the sweet psalmist of Israel. "My heart" (he says) "is inditing a good matter". The word is really "welling up a great matter". What he spoke of was not a composition of someone else. The heart of every believer ought to have a psalm, Look at David. The secret of the volume of his psalms lies in this -- that he knew God; the subjects were infinite; see the vast range of subjects covered by the psalms of David. He knew God. Then look at Solomon; where is the poet that can be compared with Solomon? His songs, we are told, were a thousand and five. Solomon was in the light of God. David says, "I speak of the things which I have made touching the king". I do appeal to you as to where you are in regard to the light you have been given. God is looking for something from believers; He looks for a song -- for fruit.
Now I want to go on to what I began with, that is God's sovereignty. Every natural heart quarrels with God's sovereign rights. What you see here is
[Page 510]
that God proposes to do certain things; He proposes to spread a feast of fat things, a feast of wines on the lees well refined; that is a very great thought; God proposes that. The next point is, where is this feast going to be spread? The prophet says, "in this mountain". On this mountain? Now do not begin to make terms with God; He will not remove the feast to your house. He will have it just here; "in this mountain" (says the prophet) "shall the Lord make a feast of fat things, a feast of wines on the lees", the feast is just there. Are you prepared to accept God's terms? He has wonderful things for you; wonderful things. You are hungry, you need food, but what He proposes is a feast, if you will agree to His terms.
You remember Luke 14; the point there is not the sovereignty of God, but God's delight in Christ as having accomplished righteousness; that is the feast in Luke 14, but it is God's feast, and He sends out invitations in regard to it. Christ having accomplished righteousness through dying has gone into heaven; God has reached His thought in man -- in Christ, and God celebrates it. The feast in Luke 14is not your celebration. I have been dwelling on that; but here in Luke 14it is God who celebrates it. God Himself celebrates the great end He has achieved in Christ, and He invites you to it. Nothing could be greater grace than that. He is indicating in that scene His infinite delight in Christ, and He invites you to it. Think of the hardness of men's hearts to reject such an offer; they prefer the things on earth to that -- the earth that is about to be turned upside down, they prefer that to God's celebration of Christ as the accomplisher of righteousness.
In this chapter it is God spreading a feast in another place; it is another thought. The feast is just where God has placed it, will you accept it? Are you prepared to come to it? You may say. Why on
[Page 511]
that mountain? If you come you will find out. When I say that, I say it advisedly; you will not understand the mountain until you come; that "mountain" involves a great deal on God's account; spiritually it is Christ risen, and when you come you will discover it. God has sovereign rights, and you must admit that He has God, as it were, will have nothing to do with you until you admit it; He shuts up all in unbelief until His sovereign rights are admitted. He says of that mountain the feast is there. Now when you come to that mountain what do you find? What have we believers found? What I have found on it among other things is this, it is God's rest, "This is my rest for ever", this mount Zion, "here will I dwell, for I have desired it", Psalm 132:14. When you come to it you will find that out. You may not think of God's rest for the moment or of His dwelling, but you have some appreciation of "a feast of fat things", for you need that, and if you come you will find what every believer has found in recognising the sovereign rights of God, that He has a place in which He rests, and that is in CHRIST RISEN, that is what the mountain means; it is Christ risen. God will not be diverted from that, He rests in Christ risen. "Here" (He says) "will I dwell, for I have desired it".
Zion is the spot where God proposes to do everything. You remember the connection of mount Zion? It is the great central point in the history of David. The history of mount Zion is that everything was lost in the point of responsibility, and "The Lord awaked as one out of sleep, and like a mighty man that shouteth by reason of wine. And he smote his enemies in the hinder parts, he put them to a perpetual reproach. Moreover he refused the tabernacle of Joseph, and chose not the tribe of Ephraim: but chose the tribe of Judah, the mount Zion which he loved", Psalm 78:65 - 68. He chose that deliberately.
[Page 512]
What it means spiritually is that God has raised Christ out of death and He will not be diverted from that.
